Authors:
Yu Ito, Norio Tanaka, Dirk Carl Albach, Anders S Barfod,
Bengt Oxelman, A. Muthama Muasya
Title:
Molecular phylogeny of the cosmopolitan aquatic plant genus
Limosella (Scrophulariaceae) with a particular focus on the origin of
the Australasian L. curdieana
Keywords:
Aquatic plants, Lamiales, Dispersal, Molecular phylogeny,
Biogeography
Abstract:
Limosella is a small aquatic genus of Scrophulariaceae of
nine to twelve species, of which six to eight are distributed in Africa
and two to four occur elsewhere in either the Northern or Southern
Hemisphere, with two to three found in Australasia. The Australasian L.
curdieana has always been considered distinct but no relative has been
suggested or its phylogenetic origin been inferred. Here, the following
alternative phylogenetic hypotheses of L. curdieana are proposed based
on comparative leaf morphology and habitat preferences or floral
morphology: i) sister to the African L. grandiflora; or ii) closely
related to a group of other African species and the northern circumpolar
L. aquatica. We tested these hypotheses in a phylogenetic framework
using DNA sequence data from four plastid DNA regions and the nuclear
ITS region. These were analyzed using maximum parsimony and Bayesian
inference. We obtained moderately resolved, partially conflicting
phylogenies, supporting that accessions of L. grandiflora form the most
basal monophyletic group and that L. curdieana groups with African L.
africana and L. major, and L. aquatica. The molecular evidence thus
clearly supports the second hypothesis. The overall phylogenetic results
suggest an out-of-Southern Africa scenario and several dispersal events
in the Southern Hemisphere. Past dispersal from southern Africa to
Australasia via tropical Africa and Asia is an exciting possibility that
should be tested for when further evidence becomes available.
